elements.content: <ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="simple-para0025" view="all">A new copper-complex fragment-substituted β-octamolybdate, K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[{Cu(phen)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>][Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phenanthroline), has been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. The compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is first observation of one-dimensional linear chain structure containing transition-metal-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate fragments [{Cu(phen)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>] and [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> clusters.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A new copper-complex fragment-substituted β-octamolybdate, K2[{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22][Mo8O26]⋅2H3O (1) (phen=1,10-phenanthroline), has been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. The compound 1 is first observation of one-dimensional linear chain structure containing transition-metal-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate fragments [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22] and [β-Mo8O26]4- clusters.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="simple-para0030" view="all">A copper-complex fragments-substituted β-octamolybdate, K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[{Cu(phen)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>][Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phenanthroline), has been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized for the first time. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is constructed from transition-metal-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate fragment [{Cu(phen)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>] and [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster to form one-dimensional (1D) linear chain. Furthermore, magnetic measurements show weak ferromagnetic interactions for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A copper-complex fragments-substituted β-octamolybdate, K2[{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22][Mo8O26]⋅2H3O (1) (phen=1,10-phenanthroline), has been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized for the first time. Compound 1 is constructed from transition-metal-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate fragment [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22] and [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster to form one-dimensional (1D) linear chain. Furthermore, magnetic measurements show weak ferromagnetic interactions for compound 1.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0005" view="all">Polyoxometalates (POMs), as one kind of significant metal oxide clusters with abundant topologies, have many properties that make them attractive for applications in catalysis, materials science, medicine, photochemistry and electrochemistry . During the past decades, extensive efforts have been devoted to the direct grafting of organic substrates on the nucleophilic oxygen atoms of the POMs core and to the introduction of organometallic fragments into lacunary POMs complexes . Recently, a large number of novel inorganic–metalorganic hybrid solid materials combining between transition metal complexes (TMCs) and POMs have been reported . However, one of the crucial strategies for molecular design of this type of solid materials is how to employ a hydrothermal synthesis method to manufacture some interesting transition-metal-substituted polyoxometalates (TMSPs), which remains largely unexplored. Most of reported TMSPs incorporating TMCs were synthesized by the reactions of lacunary POMs precursors and TMCs, for example, [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>(α-AsW<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">33</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup>, [α<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>W<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">61</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">10−</ce:sup>, [(γ-SiW<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ-1,1,1-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-1,1-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">12−</ce:sup>, [(SiW<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">34</ce:inf>)(SiW<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">33</ce:inf>(OH))(Cu(OH))<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Cu]<ce:sup loc="post">11−</ce:sup>
, and so on. Only a few of reported TMSPs were obtained by hydrothermal method, such as [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(2,2′-bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)][GeW<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">31</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and [Cd(dien)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[(dien)CdAs<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>V<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">41</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O . Synthesis of compounds of TMSPs incorporating TMCs with unexpected structures and properties is a great challenge, further research is necessary to enrich and develop this branch. As a part of our effort in the hydrothermal assembly of new solid materials , we focus on the coupling of organic molecules to keystone hybrid structures to form novel material from TMSPs building block by hydrothermal reaction. In the last couple of years we have witnessed the discovery of transition-metal-substituted heteropolyanion incorporating TMCs . So far, transition-metal-substituted isopolyanion incorporating TMCs has not been reported yet. Herein, we report the hydrothermal synthesis, structural characterization and magnetic properties of a novel copper-complex fragments-substituted isopolyanion compound: K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[{Cu(phen)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>][Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Structural information about POMs-incorporated TM coordinated complexes is very limited. To the best of our knowledge, Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is observed firstly with copper-complex fragments-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup>. Furthermore, magnetic properties of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> have been studied in the temperature range 2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, displaying weak ferromagnetic interactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Polyoxometalates (POMs), as one kind of significant metal oxide clusters with abundant topologies, have many properties that make them attractive for applications in catalysis, materials science, medicine, photochemistry and electrochemistry . During the past decades, extensive efforts have been devoted to the direct grafting of organic substrates on the nucleophilic oxygen atoms of the POMs core and to the introduction of organometallic fragments into lacunary POMs complexes . Recently, a large number of novel inorganic-metalorganic hybrid solid materials combining between transition metal complexes (TMCs) and POMs have been reported . However, one of the crucial strategies for molecular design of this type of solid materials is how to employ a hydrothermal synthesis method to manufacture some interesting transition-metal-substituted polyoxometalates (TMSPs), which remains largely unexplored. Most of reported TMSPs incorporating TMCs were synthesized by the reactions of lacunary POMs precursors and TMCs, for example, [Cu4K2(H2O)8(α-AsW9O33)2]8-, [α2-P2W17O61]10-, [(γ-SiW10O36)2Cu4(μ-1,1,1-N3)2(μ-1,1-N3)2]12-, [(SiW9O34)(SiW9O33(OH))(Cu(OH))6Cu]11- , and so on. Only a few of reported TMSPs were obtained by hydrothermal method, such as [Cu5(2,2'-bpy)5(H2O)][GeW8O31]⋅9H2O and [Cd(dien)2]2[(dien)CdAs8V13O41(H2O)]⋅4H2O . Synthesis of compounds of TMSPs incorporating TMCs with unexpected structures and properties is a great challenge, further research is necessary to enrich and develop this branch. As a part of our effort in the hydrothermal assembly of new solid materials , we focus on the coupling of organic molecules to keystone hybrid structures to form novel material from TMSPs building block by hydrothermal reaction. In the last couple of years we have witnessed the discovery of transition-metal-substituted heteropolyanion incorporating TMCs . So far, transition-metal-substituted isopolyanion incorporating TMCs has not been reported yet. Herein, we report the hydrothermal synthesis, structural characterization and magnetic properties of a novel copper-complex fragments-substituted isopolyanion compound: K2[{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22][Mo8O26]⋅2H3O, 1. Structural information about POMs-incorporated TM coordinated complexes is very limited. To the best of our knowledge, Compound 1 is observed firstly with copper-complex fragments-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo6O22]8-. Furthermore, magnetic properties of compound 1 have been studied in the temperature range 2-300K, displaying weak ferromagnetic interactions.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0010" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
 was prepared from hydrothermal reaction. A mixture of (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1.12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), KF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), phen (0.14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), and 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was stirred for 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in air. The resulting gel with a pH of 4.5–5.0 was then transferred to a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 6 days. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, green block crystals were isolated in 37% yield (based on Mo).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 1  was prepared from hydrothermal reaction. A mixture of (NH4)6Mo7O24 ⋅4H2O (1.12g), CuSO4 ⋅5H2O (0.11g), KF⋅2H2O (0.15g), phen (0.14g), and 10ml H2O was stirred for 40min in air. The resulting gel with a pH of 4.5-5.0 was then transferred to a 20mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 160°C for 6 days. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, green block crystals were isolated in 37% yield (based on Mo).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0015" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis  revealed the existence of the dilacunary species, [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup>, which is a new member for the POMs family. The dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is derived from saturated β-octamolybdate through the removal of two MoO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> groups (). The molecule structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of copper-complex fragments-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate unit [{Cu(phen)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>], a [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster, two protoned water molecules and a K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the first transition-metal-substituted derivative of [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>. An ORTEP drawing of the asymmetry unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with the atom-labeling scheme is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, which includes only seven molybdenum and two copper atoms. The well-known [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster consists of eight distorted corner- and/or edge-sharing MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra  with Mo–O distances in the range 1.690(3)–2.446(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and bond angles in the range 69.30(8)–174.34(11)°. Each [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster forms covalent interactions with two [Cu(phen)] complexes through bridging terminal oxo-groups of β-octamolybdate. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>, [{Cu(phen)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>] fragment is a 2D network, which is composed of dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> linked with four [Cu(phen)] complexes by sharing oxygen atoms. Molybdenum oxo-groups of [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> anion possess two coordination modes, MoO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> square pyramidal geometry and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedron. The [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> anion acts as a multidentate ligand linked with Cu ions. The lacunary sites of [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> anion are occupied by four [Cu(phen)] complexes to form a Cu-complex fragments-substituted POMs. The Cu1 atom locates in the {CuO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} square pyramid corner-sharing with a MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedron and a MoO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> square pyramid (Cu–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.970(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), bonds to two terminal oxo-groups of two MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra belonging to the [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster (Cu–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.394(3) Å) and dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> (Cu–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.959(2) Å), respectively, and contacts with two nitrogen donors of one phen ligand (Cu–N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.995(3)−2.017(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The Cu2 atom locates in the {CuO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} planar square corner-sharing with a MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedron and a MoO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> square pyramid (Cu–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.929(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), bonds to a terminal O atom of the corner-shared MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedron (Cu–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.944(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), and contacts with two nitrogen donors of one phen ligand (Cu–N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.971(3)−1.975(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Distance of Cu1···Cu2 is 4.095<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Cu1A and Cu2A are symmetrically equivalent copper atoms of Cu1 and Cu2, respectively. Their coordination environments are the same to those of Cu1 and Cu2, respectively. Therefore, the structure may also be described as four [Cu(phen)] complexes that take the place of two MoO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> groups located symmetrically in the [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> shell to form the hybrid [{Cu(phen)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>] fragment. [{Cu(phen)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>] fragment and [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster are alternatively adjacent to each other and connected via terminal O atom of MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedron to form a novel 1D linear chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). The isolated K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations and protoned water molecules acting as charge-compensating cations, occupy inter-chain (SI.1). The bond valence sum calculations  for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicate that all Mo atoms are in the +6 oxidation state with an average value of 5.939, all Cu atoms are in the +2 oxidation state with an average value of 1.686. Direct evidence for this is also provided by XPS measurements. As shown in the XPS spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>(SI.2), two peaks at 232.4 and 235.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>eV can be attributed to Mo<ce:sup loc="post">6+</ce:sup> (3d<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>) and Mo<ce:sup loc="post">6+</ce:sup> (3d<ce:inf loc="post">3/2</ce:inf>), respectively . The two peaks at 934.3 and 954.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>eV can be attributed to Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (2p<ce:inf loc="post">3/2</ce:inf>) and Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (2p<ce:inf loc="post">1/2</ce:inf>), respectively .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis  revealed the existence of the dilacunary species, [Mo6O22]8-, which is a new member for the POMs family. The dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo6O22]8- in 1 is derived from saturated β-octamolybdate through the removal of two MoO2 groups (). The molecule structure of compound 1 consists of copper-complex fragments-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate unit [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22], a [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster, two protoned water molecules and a K+ cation. Compound 1 is the first transition-metal-substituted derivative of [β-Mo8O26]4-. An ORTEP drawing of the asymmetry unit of 1 with the atom-labeling scheme is shown in  , which includes only seven molybdenum and two copper atoms. The well-known [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster consists of eight distorted corner- and/or edge-sharing MoO6 octahedra  with Mo-O distances in the range 1.690(3)-2.446(2)Å and bond angles in the range 69.30(8)-174.34(11)°. Each [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster forms covalent interactions with two [Cu(phen)] complexes through bridging terminal oxo-groups of β-octamolybdate. As shown in  , [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22] fragment is a 2D network, which is composed of dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo6O22]8- linked with four [Cu(phen)] complexes by sharing oxygen atoms. Molybdenum oxo-groups of [Mo6O22]8- anion possess two coordination modes, MoO5 square pyramidal geometry and MoO6 octahedron. The [Mo6O22]8- anion acts as a multidentate ligand linked with Cu ions. The lacunary sites of [Mo6O22]8- anion are occupied by four [Cu(phen)] complexes to form a Cu-complex fragments-substituted POMs. The Cu1 atom locates in the {CuO3N2} square pyramid corner-sharing with a MoO6 octahedron and a MoO5 square pyramid (Cu-O=1.970(2)Å), bonds to two terminal oxo-groups of two MoO6 octahedra belonging to the [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster (Cu-O=2.394(3) Å) and dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo6O22]8- (Cu-O=1.959(2) Å), respectively, and contacts with two nitrogen donors of one phen ligand (Cu-N=1.995(3)-2.017(3)Å). The Cu2 atom locates in the {CuO2N2} planar square corner-sharing with a MoO6 octahedron and a MoO5 square pyramid (Cu-O=1.929(2)Å), bonds to a terminal O atom of the corner-shared MoO6 octahedron (Cu-O=1.944(3)Å), and contacts with two nitrogen donors of one phen ligand (Cu-N=1.971(3)-1.975(3)Å). Distance of Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 is 4.095Å. Cu1A and Cu2A are symmetrically equivalent copper atoms of Cu1 and Cu2, respectively. Their coordination environments are the same to those of Cu1 and Cu2, respectively. Therefore, the structure may also be described as four [Cu(phen)] complexes that take the place of two MoO2 groups located symmetrically in the [β-Mo8O26]4- shell to form the hybrid [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22] fragment. [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22] fragment and [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster are alternatively adjacent to each other and connected via terminal O atom of MoO6 octahedron to form a novel 1D linear chain ( ). The isolated K+ cations and protoned water molecules acting as charge-compensating cations, occupy inter-chain (SI.1). The bond valence sum calculations  for compound 1 indicate that all Mo atoms are in the +6 oxidation state with an average value of 5.939, all Cu atoms are in the +2 oxidation state with an average value of 1.686. Direct evidence for this is also provided by XPS measurements. As shown in the XPS spectra of 1(SI.2), two peaks at 232.4 and 235.8eV can be attributed to Mo6+ (3d5/2) and Mo6+ (3d3/2), respectively . The two peaks at 934.3 and 954.3eV can be attributed to Cu2+ (2p3/2) and Cu2+ (2p1/2), respectively .

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0020" view="all">The TG curve shows two major weight losses in the regions of 346–366<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 380–440<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (SI.3), respectively. The first step corresponds to the loss of two protoned water molecules (exptl 1.15%, calcd 1.19%). The second huge mass loss can be assigned to the phen ligands (exptl 21.11%, calcd 22.51%). The relatively high temperature of dehydration for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reflects the presence of all water molecules as structural water, rather than as waters of crystallization .</ce:para>

elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibilities of 1 measured at a field of 1000 Oe and in the temperature range of 2-300K are shown in  . When the compound was cooled from room temperature, the value of χ m T increased continuously to a maximum of 1.85emuKmol-1 at 9K, which indicates the existence of ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu2+ ions. Below 9K, the value of χ m T drops sharply to 1.07emuKmol-1 at 2K. Between 300K and 20K, the measured data are fitted using the Curie-Weiss equation, χ m = C/(T-θ), where C =1.65emuKmol-1 and θ =2.12K. This fact further confirms the existence of weak ferromagnetic interactions. The room temperature χ m T value of 1.66emuKmol-1 is close to the spin-only value of 1.65emuKmol-1 expected for four independent Cu2+ ions (g =2.1) . This also supports the presence of four isolated Cu2+ ions with weak ferromagnetic interactions.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0030" view="all">In conclusion, the Cu-complex fragments-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate has been prepared through using TMCs under hydrothermal conditions. Especially, the dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> is first reported. Notably, the TMCs can stabilize the lacunary POMs species formed in situ. By further changing the type of TMCs, novel TMSPs may be obtained under proper conditions. This work demonstrates that it is a feasible route to build up functionalized low-dimension solid-state materials by using oxomolybdate as building units. It can be anticipated that this will provide some help for the construction of extended TMSPs frameworks with unexpected structures and properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, the Cu-complex fragments-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate has been prepared through using TMCs under hydrothermal conditions. Especially, the dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo6O22]8- is first reported. Notably, the TMCs can stabilize the lacunary POMs species formed in situ. By further changing the type of TMCs, novel TMSPs may be obtained under proper conditions. This work demonstrates that it is a feasible route to build up functionalized low-dimension solid-state materials by using oxomolybdate as building units. It can be anticipated that this will provide some help for the construction of extended TMSPs frameworks with unexpected structures and properties.

<ce:para id="para0010" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
 was prepared from hydrothermal reaction. A mixture of (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1.12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), KF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), phen (0.14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), and 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was stirred for 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in air. The resulting gel with a pH of 4.5–5.0 was then transferred to a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 6 days. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, green block crystals were isolated in 37% yield (based on Mo).</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: Compound 1  was prepared from hydrothermal reaction. A mixture of (NH4)6Mo7O24 ⋅4H2O (1.12g), CuSO4 ⋅5H2O (0.11g), KF⋅2H2O (0.15g), phen (0.14g), and 10ml H2O was stirred for 40min in air. The resulting gel with a pH of 4.5-5.0 was then transferred to a 20mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 160°C for 6 days. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, green block crystals were isolated in 37% yield (based on Mo).

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0015" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis  revealed the existence of the dilacunary species, [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup>, which is a new member for the POMs family. The dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is derived from saturated β-octamolybdate through the removal of two MoO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> groups (). The molecule structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of copper-complex fragments-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate unit [{Cu(phen)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>], a [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster, two protoned water molecules and a K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the first transition-metal-substituted derivative of [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>. An ORTEP drawing of the asymmetry unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with the atom-labeling scheme is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, which includes only seven molybdenum and two copper atoms. The well-known [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster consists of eight distorted corner- and/or edge-sharing MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra  with Mo–O distances in the range 1.690(3)–2.446(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and bond angles in the range 69.30(8)–174.34(11)°. Each [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster forms covalent interactions with two [Cu(phen)] complexes through bridging terminal oxo-groups of β-octamolybdate. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>, [{Cu(phen)}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>] fragment is a 2D network, which is composed of dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> linked with four [Cu(phen)] complexes by sharing oxygen atoms. Molybdenum oxo-groups of [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> anion possess two coordination modes, MoO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> square pyramidal geometry and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedron. The [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> anion acts as a multidentate ligand linked with Cu ions. The lacunary sites of [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> anion are occupied by four [Cu(phen)] complexes to form a Cu-complex fragments-substituted POMs. The Cu1 atom locates in the {CuO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} square pyramid corner-sharing with a MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedron and a MoO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> square pyramid (Cu–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.970(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), bonds to two terminal oxo-groups of two MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra belonging to the [β-Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster (Cu–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.394(3) Å) and dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">8−</ce:sup> (Cu–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.959(2) Å), respectively, and contacts with two nitrogen donors of one phen ligand (Cu–N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.995(3)−2.017(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The Cu2 atom locates in the {CuO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} planar square corner-sharing with a MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedron and a MoO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> square pyramid (Cu–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.929(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), bonds to a terminal O atom of the corner-shared MoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedron (Cu–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.944(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), and contacts with two nitrogen donors of one phen ligand (Cu–N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.971(3)−1.975(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Distance of Cu1···Cu2 is 4.095<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Cu1A and Cu2A are symmetrically equivalent copper atoms of Cu1 and Cu2, respectively. Their coordination environments are the same to those of Cu1 and Cu2, respectively. cln_elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis  revealed the existence of the dilacunary species, [Mo6O22]8-, which is a new member for the POMs family. The dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo6O22]8- in 1 is derived from saturated β-octamolybdate through the removal of two MoO2 groups (). The molecule structure of compound 1 consists of copper-complex fragments-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate unit [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22], a [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster, two protoned water molecules and a K+ cation. Compound 1 is the first transition-metal-substituted derivative of [β-Mo8O26]4-. An ORTEP drawing of the asymmetry unit of 1 with the atom-labeling scheme is shown in  , which includes only seven molybdenum and two copper atoms. The well-known [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster consists of eight distorted corner- and/or edge-sharing MoO6 octahedra  with Mo-O distances in the range 1.690(3)-2.446(2)Å and bond angles in the range 69.30(8)-174.34(11)°. Each [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster forms covalent interactions with two [Cu(phen)] complexes through bridging terminal oxo-groups of β-octamolybdate. As shown in  , [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22] fragment is a 2D network, which is composed of dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo6O22]8- linked with four [Cu(phen)] complexes by sharing oxygen atoms. Molybdenum oxo-groups of [Mo6O22]8- anion possess two coordination modes, MoO5 square pyramidal geometry and MoO6 octahedron. The [Mo6O22]8- anion acts as a multidentate ligand linked with Cu ions. The lacunary sites of [Mo6O22]8- anion are occupied by four [Cu(phen)] complexes to form a Cu-complex fragments-substituted POMs. The Cu1 atom locates in the {CuO3N2} square pyramid corner-sharing with a MoO6 octahedron and a MoO5 square pyramid (Cu-O=1.970(2)Å), bonds to two terminal oxo-groups of two MoO6 octahedra belonging to the [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster (Cu-O=2.394(3) Å) and dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo6O22]8- (Cu-O=1.959(2) Å), respectively, and contacts with two nitrogen donors of one phen ligand (Cu-N=1.995(3)-2.017(3)Å). The Cu2 atom locates in the {CuO2N2} planar square corner-sharing with a MoO6 octahedron and a MoO5 square pyramid (Cu-O=1.929(2)Å), bonds to a terminal O atom of the corner-shared MoO6 octahedron (Cu-O=1.944(3)Å), and contacts with two nitrogen donors of one phen ligand (Cu-N=1.971(3)-1.975(3)Å). Distance of Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 is 4.095Å. Cu1A and Cu2A are symmetrically equivalent copper atoms of Cu1 and Cu2, respectively. Their coordination environments are the same to those of Cu1 and Cu2, respectively. Therefore, the structure may also be described as four [Cu(phen)] complexes that take the place of two MoO2 groups located symmetrically in the [β-Mo8O26]4- shell to form the hybrid [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22] fragment. [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22] fragment and [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster are alternatively adjacent to each other and connected via terminal O atom of MoO6 octahedron to form a novel 1D linear chain ( ). The isolated K+ cations and protoned water molecules acting as charge-compensating cations, occupy inter-chain (SI.1). The bond valence sum calculations  for compound 1 indicate that all Mo atoms are in the +6 oxidation state with an average value of 5.939, all Cu atoms are in the +2 oxidation state with an average value of 1.686. Direct evidence for this is also provided by XPS measurements. As shown in the XPS spectra of 1(SI.2), two peaks at 232.4 and 235.8eV can be attributed to Mo6+ (3d5/2) and Mo6+ (3d3/2), respectively . The two peaks at 934.3 and 954.3eV can be attributed to Cu2+ (2p3/2) and Cu2+ (2p1/2), respectively .

The TG curve shows two major weight losses in the regions of 346-366°C and 380-440°C (SI.3), respectively. The first step corresponds to the loss of two protoned water molecules (exptl 1.15%, calcd 1.19%). The second huge mass loss can be assigned to the phen ligands (exptl 21.11%, calcd 22.51%). The relatively high temperature of dehydration for 1 reflects the presence of all water molecules as structural water, rather than as waters of crystallization .

The magnetic susceptibilities of 1 measured at a field of 1000 Oe and in the temperature range of 2-300K are shown in  . When the compound was cooled from room temperature, the value of χ m T increased continuously to a maximum of 1.85emuKmol-1 at 9K, which indicates the existence of ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu2+ ions. Below 9K, the value of χ m T drops sharply to 1.07emuKmol-1 at 2K. Between 300K and 20K, the measured data are fitted using the Curie-Weiss equation, χ m = C/(T-θ), where C =1.65emuKmol-1 and θ =2.12K. This fact further confirms the existence of weak ferromagnetic interactions. The room temperature χ m T value of 1.66emuKmol-1 is close to the spin-only value of 1.65emuKmol-1 expected for four independent Cu2+ ions (g =2.1) . This also supports the presence of four isolated Cu2+ ions with weak ferromagnetic interactions.

 Crystal data for 1: K2[{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22][Mo8O26]⋅2H3O, triclinic, space group   P   1   ¯    , a =10.7825(6)Å, b =13.4970(7)Å, c =14.2316(7)Å, β =70.8590(10)°, V =1852.06(17)Å3, Z =1, D c =2.871mg/m3, F (000) =1524, λ(MoKα)=0.71073Å, T =273K, R int =0.0138. Structure solution and refinement based on 8987 independent reflections with I >2σ(I) and 632 parameters gave R 1 (wR 2)=0.0252 (0.0616) and S =1.040.
